awd_titl_txt: Travel: International Workshop on Numerical Modeling of Earthquake Motions: Waves and Ruptures
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will support 14 students and early career researchers to attend the “Numerical modeling of earthquake motions: Waves and ruptures” meeting in Smolenice, Slovakia. The workshop will explore significant advances in ground motion simulation, dynamic rupture modeling, and earthquake cycle modeling. This international workshop will bring together modelers from different countries with observational seismologists and experimentalists, facilitating exchange of scientific knowledge and ideas. 

Over three days, through a mixture of talks, poster sessions, and informal conversations, participants will discuss a wide range of topics: numerical methods, verification and validation, source inversion, friction experiments, rheology of the crust and upper mantle, the earthquake energy balance, seismic observables and their link to source processes. International scientific exchange serves to enhance productivity and excellence, as well as train the next generation of seismologists and experts in earthquake source processes and computational seismology.Funding  will support approximately 14 U.S. students, early career scientists, and members of underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided travel funding for US-based participants to attend an international workshop "Numerical Modeling of Earthquake Motions: Waves and Ruptures" that was held June 23-27, 2024, at Smolenice Castle near Bratislava, Slovakia. This workshop was the sixth such workshop to be held at this venue and on this topic since the inaugural workshop in 2003. The workshop was attended by approximately 80 people, with the majority from Europe but including others from Asia and the US. Many of the attendees were students, postdocs, or early career researchers. The small size of the workshop provided the opportunity to mix across career stages with lengthy, in-depth conversations that could focus on the technical aspects of the field. A blend of 40 talks, 33 posters, and unstructured time for more informal discussions gave everyone an opportunity to present their research, receive feedback, and exchange ideas.

The workshop was focused on the development and use of computer simulations to study earthquakes and the ground shaking that they produce. Earthquakes are a major hazard in the US and worldwide. Computer simulations of earthquakes and ground shaking are used to inform building codes, set earthquake insurance rates, and guide activities by governments and other organizations that are related to earthquake hazards. This workshop provided a unique opportunity for focused discussion among world experts in this discipline. Furthermore, the inclusion of students, postdocs, and early career scientists in this small workshop allowed for advanced training for the future generation of experts in the discipline. Travel funding was allocated to 16 US-based participants: 1 undergrad student, 1 MS student, 9 PhD students, 3 postdocs, 1 early career assistant professor, and 1 mid career associate professor.

The 77 abstracts from the workshop were compiled in a Proceedings of the Workshop volume that is available to the public on the meeting website (http://www.nuquake.eu/NMEM2024/). Furthermore, presenters were encouraged to provide their presentation slides or posters to share with the general public, again on the meeting website, and most presenters opted to do this.


Last Modified: 03/25/2025
Modified by: Eric M Dunham
